climbs.name: Wally George
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Todd Gordon, and Jim Angione, January 1988

content.description: An overhanging start leads to a grainy dihedral.  From a small ledge at the top of the dihedral, a committing move takes you into a hand crack.  After a few crux jamming moves, you get to the top.
content.location: This route goes up a large dihedral, around and right from Large Marge, and to the right of Devil Inside.

climbs.name: Large Marge
climbs.fa: Marge Floyd and Todd Gordon, January 1988

content.description: This finger and hand crack is better than it looks from the ground.  The crux is the exit move.
content.location: This is around the corner to the left of Devil Inside; a straight-in crack on the left side of the wall, facing the road.

content.description: This is an o.k. crack and face route; a right-facing flake is a useful feature on the climb.  The Bartlett guide calls it The Griswolds and the Vogel guide calls it Hotseat.
content.location: This is ten feet to the right of Large Marge, on the same wall.

climbs.name: Devil Inside
climbs.fa: (TR) D. Evans, T. Gordon & J. Angione 1/88; FL: D. Evans & C. Fry

content.description: Climb steep moves past a horizontal crack to knobs and mantle a small ledge. Continue straight up to the right end of the ledge that crosses the face. Lean out right and latch the patina plate (shaped vaguely like the state of Calif.). Climb to the top of this and reach the top.  Al's book shows it incorrectly traversing off on the ledge which crosses the face. With 2 more bolts it would actually be fun, too scary otherwise.
content.protection: The pro on this route is sketchy at best. A cam in the horizontal crack and a 1/4" bolt protect steep moves to a small ledge. There may be a runner placement here. One hangerless 1/4" bolt takes you to the top.
